key_mistakes.reason: Allows White to capture and gain a central pawn advantage.
Develops a piece but allows White to maintain central control.
Attempts a check but loses tempo and allows White to develop comfortably.
Greedy move capturing a pawn but puts the queen in a vulnerable position.
Misplaces the knight, creating tactical vulnerabilities.
Misplaces the bishop and allows White to gain a strong initiative.
The queen is out of play and not contributing to Black's defense.
Captures a pawn but further isolates the queen from the game.
Captures a pawn but overlooks better tactical opportunities.
Allows Black to capture and maintain pressure.
Misplaces the queen and allows White to consolidate.
Puts a bishop in the line of fire and loses a tempo.
Exchanges pieces but loses material advantage.
Weakens the pawn structure and creates more weaknesses.
Opens up the position to White's advantage.

recommendations: Focus on maintaining central control without unnecessary pawn exchanges.
Avoid moving the queen too early into the opponent’s territory.
Prioritize developing pieces over capturing pawns in the opening and middle game.
Watch for tactical opportunities and threats, especially when the opponent's pieces are out of optimal positions.
